prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA – for wanting to use ‘lads’ and ‘guys’ to a mixed group
  

I play an online team game which is 99% male players. Recently we asked a girl to join our team, lets call her Jane. After match we often say stuff like ‘well done boiz’ and she told us that makes her feel like not part of the team and suggested we say something like ‘well done team’ instead. We all agreed to try, she is part of the team and as good as any of us guys. Jane has said it is difficult for a girl to play in an all male group but I don’t see why as we treat her well.

Yesterday one guy posted in group chat that he could not attend a practice and said ‘Have fun lads and Jane’. Jane responded by telling him that was worse than just saying ‘lads’ and made her feel ‘othered’.

The group had a bit of a chat about it and I said I was gonna keep using ‘lads’ and ‘guys’ because I mean the whole team when I say that and I am not giving in to radical feminism. 

The guy who started this though, said he was sorry for what he wrote and he was trying to include her and he would try to refer to team or people in future.

I ought to be able to use normal words without overly sensitive people feeling hurt by it. I am surprised that some of the other guys are taking her side though.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, so the user is asking if the author is in the wrong in this situation. Let me break down the scenario.

The author is part of a mostly male online gaming team that recently added a female member, Jane. Jane has expressed feeling excluded when they use terms like "lads" and "guys," so they agreed to use "team" instead. However, the author insists on using "lads" and "guys," claiming they mean the whole team and that they shouldn't have to change for "overly sensitive" people. Another teammate apologized for using "lads and Jane" after Jane felt othered, and he'll use "team" now. The author, though, is pushing back against changing their language.

The key points here are about inclusivity and respect for Jane's feelings. The author argues that Jane is overreacting and that they shouldn't have to adjust their language. But Jane has clearly communicated that these terms make her feel excluded. Even though the author intends to include everyone, the impact on Jane is negative. The other teammate acknowledged the mistake and changed behavior, which the author didn't do. The author's stance seems dismissive of Jane's valid feelings. Inclusivity often requires adjusting language to make everyone feel welcome, even if it's not the intention of the words. So, the author is likely in the wrong by refusing to adapt and maintaining that Jane is being too sensitive. The answer is A.
